13.00.text: One of my favorite cartoon characters is Snoopy.

18.00.text: I love the way he sits and lies on his kennel and contemplates the great things of life.

25.00.text: So when I thought about compassion,

27.00.text: my mind immediately went to one of the cartoon strips,

31.00.text: where he's lying there and he says,

35.00.text: "I really understand, and I really appreciate

38.00.text: how one should love one's neighbor as one love's oneself.

43.00.text: The only trouble is the people next door; I can't stand them."

48.00.text: This, in a way, is one of the challenges

53.00.text: of how to interpret a really good idea.

57.00.text: We all, I think, believe in compassion.

60.00.text: If you look at all the world religions, all the main world religions,

64.00.text: you'll find within them some teaching concerning compassion.

69.00.text: So in Judaism, we have, from our Torah,

72.00.text: that you should love your neighbor as you love yourself.

76.00.text: And within Jewish teachings, the rabbinic teachings, we have Hillel,

81.00.text: who taught that you shouldn't do to others what you don't like being done to yourself.

86.00.text: And all the main religions have similar teachings.

93.00.text: we have a teaching about God,

96.00.text: who is called the compassionate one, Ha-rachaman.

99.00.text: After all, how could the world exist without God being compassionate?

104.00.text: And we, as taught within the Torah that we are made in the image of God,

109.00.text: so we too have to be compassionate.

113.00.text: But what does it mean? How does it impact on our everyday life?

121.00.text: can produce feelings within us that are very difficult to control.

128.00.text: I know there are many times when I've gone and conducted a funeral,

134.00.text: or when I have been sitting with the bereaved, or with people who are dying,

140.00.text: and I am overwhelmed by the sadness, by the difficulty,

149.00.text: the challenge that is there for the family, for the person.

153.00.text: And I'm touched, so that tears come to my eyes.

158.00.text: And yet, if I just allowed myself to be overwhelmed by these feelings,

163.00.text: I wouldn't be doing my job --

166.00.text: because I have to actually be there for them

168.00.text: and make sure that rituals happen, that practicalities are seen to.

176.00.text: And yet, on the other hand, if I didn't feel this compassion,

181.00.text: then I feel that it would be time for me to hang up my robe

186.00.text: and give up being a rabbi.

189.00.text: And these same feelings are there for all of us as we face the world.

194.00.text: Who cannot be touched by compassion

198.00.text: when we see the terrible horrors of the results of war,

205.00.text: or famine, or earthquakes, or tsunamis?

210.00.text: I know some people who say

212.00.text: "Well, you know there's just so much out there -- I can't do anything,

216.00.text: I'm not going to even begin to try."

220.00.text: And there are some charity workers who call this compassion fatigue.

226.00.text: There are others who feel they can't confront compassion anymore,

233.00.text: and so they turn off the television and don't watch.

238.00.text: In Judaism, though, we tend to always say, there has to be a middle way.

245.00.text: You have to, of course, be aware of the needs of others,

252.00.text: but you have to be aware in such a way that you can carry on with your life

257.00.text: and be of help to people.

260.00.text: So part of compassion has to be an understanding of what makes people tick.

269.00.text: And, of course, you can't do that unless you understand yourself a bit more.

272.00.text: And there's a lovely rabbinic interpretation of the beginnings of creation,

279.00.text: which says that when God created the world,

283.00.text: God thought that it would be best to create the world

289.00.text: only with the divine attribute of justice.

293.00.text: Because, after all, God is just.

295.00.text: Therefore, there should be justice throughout the world.

300.00.text: And then God looked to the future and realized,

302.00.text: if the world was created just with justice, the world couldn't exist.

307.00.text: So, God thought, "Nope, I'm going to create the world just with compassion."

313.00.text: And then God looked to the future and realized that,

317.00.text: in fact, if the world were just filled with compassion,

321.00.text: there would be anarchy and chaos.

325.00.text: There had to be limits to all things.

328.00.text: The rabbis describe this as being like a king

333.00.text: who has a beautiful, fragile glass bowl.

339.00.text: If you put too much cold water in, it will shatter.

343.00.text: If you put boiling water in, it will shatter.

345.00.text: What do you have to do? Put in a mixture of the two.

350.00.text: And so God put both of these possibilities into the world.

358.00.text: There is something more though that has to be there.

362.00.text: And that is the translation of the feelings

367.00.text: that we may have about compassion

370.00.text: into the wider world, into action.

374.00.text: So, like Snoopy, we can't just lie there

377.00.text: and think great thoughts about our neighbors.

380.00.text: We actually have to do something about it.

383.00.text: And so there is also, within Judaism, this notion of love and kindness

393.00.text: All these three things, then, have to be melded together.

398.00.text: The idea of justice, which gives boundaries to our lives

404.00.text: and gives us a feeling of what's right about life, what's right about living,

411.00.text: what should we be doing, social justice.

415.00.text: There has to be a willingness to do good deeds,

420.00.text: but not, of course, at the expense of our own sanity.

429.00.text: And balancing them all in the middle is this notion of compassion,

435.00.text: which has to be there, if you like, at our very roots.

441.00.text: This idea of compassion comes to us

446.00.text: because we're made in the image of God,

449.00.text: who is ultimately the compassionate one.

455.00.text: It entails understanding the pain of the other.

462.00.text: it means understanding one's connection to the whole of creation:

470.00.text: understanding that one is part of that creation,

474.00.text: that there is a unity that underlies all that we see,

478.00.text: all that we hear, all that we feel.

485.00.text: And that unity is something that connects all of creation.

490.00.text: And, of course, in the modern world, with the environmental movement,

493.00.text: we're becoming even more aware of the connectivity of things,

498.00.text: that something I do here actually does matter in Africa,

503.00.text: that if I use too much of my carbon allowance,

507.00.text: it seems to be that we are causing

509.00.text: a great lack of rain in central and eastern Africa.

518.00.text: and I have to understand that -- as part of the creation,

524.00.text: as part of me being made in the image of God.

529.00.text: And I have to understand that my needs

533.00.text: sometimes have to be sublimated to other needs.

648.00.text: Now there is, in Judaism, a gorgeous story

653.00.text: of a rich man who sat in synagogue one day.

659.00.text: And, as many people do, he was dozing off during the sermon.

665.00.text: And as he was dozing off, they were reading from the book of Leviticus in the Torah.

671.00.text: And they were saying that in the ancient times in the temple in Jerusalem,

677.00.text: the priests used to have bread,

679.00.text: which they used to place into a special table in the temple in Jerusalem.

687.00.text: The man was asleep, but he heard the words bread, temple, God, and he woke up.

694.00.text: He said, "God wants bread. That's it. God wants bread. I know what God wants."

699.00.text: And he rushed home. And after the Sabbath, he made 12 loaves of bread,

706.00.text: took them to the synagogue, went into the synagogue,

709.00.text: opened the ark and said, "God, I don't know why you want this bread, but here you are."

713.00.text: And he put it in the ark with the scrolls of the Torah.

721.00.text: The cleaner came into the synagogue.

724.00.text: "Oh God, I'm in such trouble. I've got children to feed.

728.00.text: My wife's ill. I've got no money. What can I do?"

732.00.text: He goes into the synagogue. "God, will you please help me?

738.00.text: He goes to the ark. He opens the ark.

740.00.text: "There's bread! God, you've answered my plea. You've answered my question."

745.00.text: Takes the bread and goes home.

748.00.text: Meanwhile, the rich man thinks to himself,

754.00.text: God, the one who rules the entire universe, wants my bread?"

759.00.text: He rushes to the synagogue. "I'll get it out of the ark before anybody finds it."

762.00.text: He goes in there, and it's not there.

765.00.text: And he says, "God, you really did want it. You wanted my bread.

775.00.text: Every week, the man would bring bread with raisins,

778.00.text: with all sorts of good things, put it into the ark.

781.00.text: Every week, the cleaner would come. "God you've answered my plea again."

785.00.text: Take the bread. Take it home.

787.00.text: Went on until a new rabbi came. Rabbis always spoil things.

790.00.text: The rabbi came in and saw what was going on.

795.00.text: And he called the two of them to his office.

797.00.text: And he said, you know, "This is what's happening."

800.00.text: And the rich man -- oh, dear -- crestfallen.

806.00.text: "You mean God didn't want my bread?"

810.00.text: And the poor man said, "And you mean God didn't answer my pleas?"

817.00.text: And the rabbi said, "You've misunderstood me.

824.00.text: "Of course, what you are doing," he said to the rich man,

828.00.text: "is answering God's plea that we should be compassionate.

834.00.text: And God," he said to the poor man, "is answering your plea

838.00.text: that people should be compassionate and give."

842.00.text: He looked at the rich man. He held the rich man's hands and said,

848.00.text: "Don't you understand?" He said, "These are the hands of God."

859.00.text: So that is the way I feel:

865.00.text: that I can only try to approach this notion of being compassionate,

872.00.text: of understanding that there is a connectivity, that there is a unity in this world;

878.00.text: that I want to try and serve that unity,

883.00.text: and that I can try and do that by understanding, I hope,

887.00.text: trying to understand something of the pain of others;

892.00.text: but understanding that there are limits, that people have to bear responsibility

895.00.text: for some of the problems that come upon them;

900.00.text: and that I have to understand that there are limits to my energy,

903.00.text: to the giving I can give.

909.00.text: try and separate out the material things

914.00.text: and my emotions that may be enslaving me,

918.00.text: so that I can see the world clearly.

922.00.text: And then I have to try to see in what ways

927.00.text: I can make these the hands of God.
